documents.summary: This circular allows Investment Advisers (IAs) and Research Analysts (RAs) to use liquid mutual funds and overnight mutual funds, in addition to bank deposits, to meet their deposit requirements as specified under SEBI (Investment Advisers) Regulations, 2013 and SEBI (Research Analysts) Regulations, 2014. The circular directs IAASB/RAASB (BSE Limited) to put in place necessary systems and procedures for implementation and requires IAs and RAs to comply with the deposit requirements by September 30, 2025.

key_clauses.clause_title: Deposit Requirement for Investment Advisers and Research Analysts
key_clauses.clause_content: Investment Advisers (IAs) and Research Analysts (RAs) are required to maintain a deposit of such sum as specified by SEBI from time to time, as per regulation 8 of SEBI (Investment Advisers) Regulations, 2013 and SEBI (Research Analysts) Regulations, 2014.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: IAs and RAs must maintain a specified deposit to ensure compliance with regulatory requirements.

key_clauses.clause_content: IAs and RAs can now maintain the deposit in the form of units of liquid mutual fund or an overnight mutual fund or as a deposit maintained with a scheduled bank. Such deposit shall be marked as lien in favor of IAASB or RAASB, as the case may be.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Provides IAs and RAs with more flexibility in meeting deposit requirements by allowing the use of liquid and overnight mutual funds.

key_clauses.clause_content: IAs and RAs shall comply with the deposit requirements latest by September 30, 2025.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Sets a specific deadline for IAs and RAs to adjust their deposit arrangements to comply with the new regulations.

key_clauses.clause_content: IAASB/RAASB (BSE Limited) is directed to put in place necessary systems and procedures for implementation of the provisions of this circular and bring the same to the notice of IAs/RAs.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Places responsibility on IAASB/RAASB to ensure the smooth implementation of the new regulations and to inform IAs/RAs about the changes.

key_clauses.clause_content: The provisions of this circular shall come into effect from the date of issuance of this circular.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Clarifies that the new regulations are effective immediately upon the issuance of the circular.

actionable_items.action_description: IAs and RAs must ensure that they maintain the required deposit, either in the form of a bank deposit, liquid mutual fund units, or overnight mutual fund units, marked as lien in favor of IAASB or RAASB.
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: Maintain the deposit as specified under regulation 8 of IA Regulations and RA Regulations.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Records of deposit maintained with scheduled bank or units of liquid mutual fund or overnight mutual fund.
actionable_items.monitoring_mechanism: IAASB/RAASB will monitor compliance.

actionable_items.action_description: IAASB/RAASB (BSE Limited) must put in place the necessary systems and procedures for the implementation of the provisions of this circular and bring the same to the notice of IAs/RAs.
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: Establish systems to manage and monitor the new deposit options.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Documented systems and procedures.
actionable_items.monitoring_mechanism: SEBI oversight.

documents.summary: This circular issued by SEBI eliminates transaction charges paid to mutual fund distributors. It removes paragraphs 10.4.1.b and 10.5 of the SEBI Master Circular for Mutual Funds dated June 27, 2024, which previously allowed AMCs to pay transaction charges to distributors for minimum subscription amounts of INR 10,000.

key_clauses.clause_title: Elimination of Transaction Charges to Mutual Fund Distributors
key_clauses.clause_content: Paragraphs 10.4.1.b and 10.5 of SEBI Master Circular for Mutual Funds dated June 27, 2024, which allowed AMCs to pay transaction charges to distributors, are deleted.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: AMCs are no longer permitted to pay transaction charges to mutual fund distributors, even for subscriptions exceeding INR 10,000. This impacts the revenue model of distributors and the cost structure of AMCs.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but non-compliance with SEBI regulations can result in penalties as per the SEBI Act and Mutual Funds Regulations.

key_clauses.clause_content: This circular is issued under Section 11(1) of the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992 and regulation 52(4A) of the SEBI (Mutual Funds) Regulations 1996.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Confirms the legal basis and authority for the circular, making it legally binding on all affected parties.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not applicable, as this clause defines the authority for the circular.

key_metrics.metric_description: Minimum subscription amount in INR that previously triggered eligibility for transaction charges to distributors, now irrelevant due to the circular.
key_metrics.applicable_entities: Mutual Funds, Asset Management Companies (AMCs), Mutual Fund Distributors
key_metrics.threshold_significance: Previously, a subscription amount of INR 10,000 was the minimum threshold for transaction charges. Now, this threshold is obsolete.

actionable_items.non_compliance_consequences: Penalties as per SEBI Act and Mutual Funds Regulations, including fines and potential suspension of operations.

actionable_items.documentation_needed: Revised distributor agreements.

documents.summary: This circular reviews the framework for conversion of Private Listed InvIT into Public InvIT as outlined in Chapter 14 of the Master Circular for Infrastructure Investment Trusts (InvITs) dated May 15, 2024. It streamlines requirements for minimum unitholding by sponsors and sponsor groups and aligns the procedure and disclosure requirements for public offers with those of follow-on offers.

key_clauses.clause_title: Minimum Unitholding Requirement for Sponsors and Sponsor Groups
key_clauses.clause_content: The sponsor(s) and sponsor group(s) shall comply with the minimum unitholding requirement specified in Regulation 12(3) and 12(3A) of the InvIT Regulations, as applicable, at all times.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Ensures that sponsors and sponsor groups maintain a minimum level of investment in the InvIT, aligning their interests with those of other unitholders.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Non-compliance would attract regulatory action as per InvIT Regulations.

key_clauses.clause_title: Lock-in Period for Sponsor and Sponsor Group Units
key_clauses.clause_content: The lock-in on units held by the sponsor(s) and sponsor group(s) to comply with the minimum unitholding requirement mentioned in paragraph 14.6.1 above shall be as specified in Regulation 12(5) of the InvIT Regulations.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Prevents sponsors and sponsor groups from immediately selling their units after the conversion, ensuring continued commitment to the InvIT.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Violation of lock-in provisions would attract regulatory action as per InvIT Regulations.

key_clauses.clause_title: Alignment of Public Offer Procedure with Follow-on Offer
key_clauses.clause_content: The procedure and disclosure requirements for public offer of units to convert a private listed InvIT into a public InvIT are aligned with the procedure and disclosure requirements applicable for follow-on offer.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Simplifies the process for conversion by leveraging existing regulations for follow-on offers, reducing compliance burden.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Failure to comply with follow-on offer requirements would attract regulatory action as per InvIT Regulations.

key_clauses.clause_content: For such public issue, the InvIT shall comply with the requirements for follow-on offer prescribed under InvIT Regulations and the circulars issued thereunder including any amendments thereto.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: InvITs must adhere to all rules and guidelines applicable to follow-on offers when converting from private to public.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Non-compliance with follow-on offer requirements will result in regulatory penalties.

key_clauses.clause_content: The disclosure requirements applicable for follow-on offer under InvIT Regulations shall be followed.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Ensures that investors receive adequate information about the InvIT and the public issue.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Inadequate or misleading disclosures would attract regulatory action as per InvIT Regulations.

documents.summary: This circular introduces a policy for joint annual inspections by MIIs (Stock Exchanges, Depositories, and Clearing Corporations) to ease the burden on intermediaries and improve supervision effectiveness. It outlines a framework for joint inspections, information sharing, and revised criteria for selecting entities for annual inspection, aiming for optimum resource utilization and a comprehensive view of entity operations.

key_clauses.clause_content: Entities selected for annual inspections will be inspected jointly by all exchanges along with their depository participant (DP) operations (if broker is also registered as DP) and clearing activity (if the broker is undertaking clearing for other brokers). DP operations and clearing activity undertaken by entities shall be inspected by Depositories and Clearing Corporations, respectively. This ensures that entities selected by MIIs for their annual inspection shall be inspected jointly by all MIIs at one time.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Reduces the frequency of inspections for brokers/DPs, minimizing disruption to their routine operations and optimizing resource utilization for both MIIs and intermediaries.

key_clauses.clause_content: MIIs shall establish an information sharing mechanism with one another for sharing of inspection observations of entities who hold multiple registrations with MIIs, to improve the effectiveness of supervision.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Enhances the ability of MIIs to identify and address potential risks and compliance issues across different segments and registrations held by an entity.

key_clauses.clause_content:
The criteria for annual inspection are revised as follows:
a. Top 25 entities paying high and recurring penalties for non-reporting or short reporting of margin/Client Code modification/CTCL mismatch fines or any other similar high risk compliance issue - shall be inspected irrespective of when they were last inspected.
b. Top 25 entities in terms of investor complaints and arbitration cases filed by investors, as percentage of number of active clients shall be inspected irrespective of the fact of when they were last inspected.
c. Top 25 entities based on ‘High risk score’ under Risk Based Supervision.
Entities that do not fall under any of the above categories shall be inspected by the MIIs at least once in three years.
Entities inspected in preceding two years by any of the MII’s/SEBI and/or entities that have not executed a single trade during last two financial years may not be considered for inspection under the above criteria.
Irrespective of the above, inspections of Professional Clearing Members shall be conducted jointly by Clearing Corporations once in two years.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Focuses inspection efforts on entities posing higher risks based on penalties, investor complaints, and risk scores. Provides a minimum inspection frequency for other entities and excludes inactive entities from routine inspections.

key_clauses.clause_content: MIIs have the prerogative to carry out special purpose/limited inspections based on any triggers like patterns found during investor complaint resolution/Arbitration, complaints on specific malpractices of a broker or references from various authorities. The inspection shall be irrespective of the fact of when the last inspection was carried out.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Allows MIIs to address specific concerns and investigate potential misconduct without being constrained by the regular inspection cycle.

key_clauses.clause_title: Rescission and Amendment of Existing Circulars
key_clauses.clause_content: SEBI Circular CIR/HO/MIRSD/MIRSD2/CIR/P/2017/73 dated June 30, 2017 stands rescinded and para 14 of Master Circular for Stock Brokers dated June 17, 2025 stands amended as per this circular.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Updates the regulatory framework for annual inspections, replacing the previous circular and amending the master circular for stock brokers.

key_metrics.threshold_significance: If an entity is not in the top 25 for penalties, complaints, or risk score, it will be inspected at least once every three years.

key_metrics.metric_description: Inspections of Professional Clearing Members shall be conducted jointly by Clearing Corporations once in two years.
key_metrics.threshold_significance: Professional Clearing Members will be inspected every two years.

key_metrics.calculation_method: Ranking based on investor complaints and arbitration cases as a percentage of active clients

documents.summary: This circular modifies the handling of review, appeal, or waiver requests of penalties arising from actions taken by the Member Committee (MC) of Market Infrastructure Institutions (MIIs). It mandates that requests against Internal Committee (IC) actions or actions per pre-approved policy are placed before the MC, while requests against MC actions are handled by a mechanism set up by the Governing Board with Public Interest Directors and/or Independent External Professionals.

key_clauses.clause_title: Terms of Reference of Statutory Committees
key_clauses.clause_content: The Terms of Reference (ToR) of Statutory Committees of Stock Exchanges, Clearing Corporations and Depositories (collectively referred as Market Infrastructure Institutions (MIIs)) have been prescribed under Paragraph 2.2.2 of Chapter 6 of SEBI Master Circular No. SEBI/HO/MRD-PoD2/CIR/P/2024/00181 dated December 30, 2024 for “Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations” and under Paragraph 4.66(B) of Section-4 of SEBI Master Circular No. SEBI/HO/MRD/MRD-PoD-1/P/CIR/2024/168 dated December 03, 2024 for “Depositories”.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause establishes the foundation for the regulatory framework governing the statutory committees of MIIs, ensuring they operate within defined parameters.

key_clauses.clause_title: Review, Appeal or Waiver of Penalty
key_clauses.clause_content: Any review, appeal or waiver of penalty filed shall be placed before MC for its consideration.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause outlines the initial process for handling requests for review, appeal, or waiver of penalties, ensuring that the MC considers such requests.

key_clauses.clause_title: Handling of Requests for Review, Appeal or Waiver of Penalty
key_clauses.clause_content: Any request for review, appeal or waiver of penalty filed against actions taken by the Internal Committee (IC) of the Member Committee (MC), or against actions taken by the MII as per pre-approved policy on regulatory action shall be placed before the MC for its consideration.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause specifies that requests against IC actions or actions based on pre-approved policies are to be considered by the MC.

key_clauses.clause_title: Mechanism for Handling Requests Against MC Actions
key_clauses.clause_content: Any request for review, appeal or waiver of penalty filed against actions taken by the MC from the date of implementation of this circular shall be handled by a mechanism setup by the Governing Board of the MII with Public Interest Directors and/or Independent External Professionals not forming part of the MC. The Governing Board shall issue the Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) with regard to handling of such review, appeal or waiver of penalty requests, if any, emanating out of actions taken by the MC.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause mandates a separate mechanism, independent of the MC, to handle requests against MC actions, ensuring impartiality and fairness. It also requires the Governing Board to establish an SOP.
key_clauses.effective_date: 45th day of issuance of the circular

key_clauses.clause_content: For further appeal against the decisions emanating out of the appeal mechanism of the MII, the members or participants would be free to approach appropriate authority based on the applicable laws.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This clause clarifies that members or participants can appeal decisions from the MII's appeal mechanism to appropriate authorities as per applicable laws.

documents.summary: This SEBI circular mandates compliance with the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016 by all regulated entities (REs). It aims to ensure accessibility of digital platforms for persons with disabilities in the securities market, requiring REs to implement specific measures and conduct audits to meet accessibility standards.

key_clauses.clause_content: All Regulated Entities (REs) must ensure their digital platforms comply with the provisions of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016 (RPwD Act, 2016) and corresponding rules, including Section 40 (Accessibility), Section 42 (Access to information and communication technology), Section 46 (Time limit for accessibility by service providers), and Rule 15(1)(c) of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Rules, 2017.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must modify their digital platforms to be accessible to persons with disabilities, impacting design, content, and functionality.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular

key_clauses.clause_content: REs must adhere to accessibility standards and guidelines, including Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.1 or latest version, Accessibility guidelines as described in the latest version of Guidelines for Indian Government Websites (GIGW), IS 17802: Indian Standards on Accessibility Requirements for Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Products and Services, and Provisions of the Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act, 2016 and corresponding rules.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must ensure their digital platforms meet specific technical standards for accessibility.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular

key_clauses.clause_content: Compliance with the circular must be reviewed and approved by the Managing Director, Managing Partner, or Proprietor of the RE. A senior officer must be designated as the Nodal Officer for digital accessibility compliance. In the absence of a designated Nodal Officer, the Compliance Officer or Proprietor will be the Nodal Officer.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must establish internal oversight and accountability for digital accessibility compliance.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular

key_clauses.clause_content: REs must institutionalize a grievance redressal mechanism specific to accessibility issues, including user-friendly channels such as email, helpline, and web forms for PwDs, with provisions for escalation to senior officers.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must establish a system for addressing and resolving accessibility-related complaints.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular

key_clauses.clause_content: Digital Platforms of REs must include features such as Indian Sign Language (ISL) videos, closed captioning, descriptive audio, and alternate text for images. All circulars, notices, and investor documents published in PDF or other formats must follow accessible document standards.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must enhance their digital content to be accessible to users with different disabilities.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular

key_clauses.clause_content: Training modules on digital accessibility must be part of all internal training programs for staff and third-party service providers who develop and publish content for dissemination via Digital Platforms. The Digital Platform shall be “accessible by design”.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must educate their staff and service providers on digital accessibility best practices.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular

key_clauses.clause_content: REs must ensure that digital KYC, e-KYC, and video KYC processes include alternatives to accommodate differently abled users/clients. KYC and client registration forms must include a mandatory field to indicate disability status and options to select specific provisions such as helpdesk call back for assistance.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must modify their KYC and registration processes to be accessible to persons with disabilities.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Any application of a client with disability shall be rejected by the REs only after a review by a designated human officer and the said officer shall be empowered to override automated rejections and approve applications on a case by case basis, thereby ensuring equitable access to services of the REs for persons with disabilities.

key_clauses.clause_content: REs must initiate a comprehensive accessibility audit of their digital platforms through International Association of Accessibility Professionals (IAAP). Based on the audit findings, REs must prepare and implement a plan for remediation of audit observations. All REs shall conduct annual accessibility audits of their digital platforms including websites, mobile apps, portals through IAAP certified accessibility professionals and reports shall be submitted as per the mechanism specified in direction 1.4 in Section 1 of this Annexure.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must regularly assess and improve the accessibility of their digital platforms.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular

key_clauses.clause_content: All newly developed/procured digital solutions must conform to latest WCAG, IS17802, GIGW guidelines and the provisions of the RPwD Act, 2016 and rules made thereunder. Accessibility requirements must be part of all Request for Proposals (RFPs) and procurement contracts of the REs.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: REs must ensure that new digital solutions are accessible from the outset.
key_clauses.effective_date: Date of issuance of the circular

documents.summary: This circular addresses the monitoring of the Minimum Investment Threshold under Specialized Investment Funds (SIFs). It outlines the mechanism for handling breaches of the minimum investment threshold, including freezing units, providing notice to investors, and automatic redemption if the threshold is not met within a specified timeframe. The circular aims to ensure compliance with SIF regulations and protect investor interests.

key_clauses.clause_content: The Asset Management Company shall monitor compliance with the Minimum Investment Threshold on a daily basis and ensure that there are no active breaches. The AMC shall ensure that the investor’s total investment value does not fall below the Minimum Investment Threshold due to redemption transactions initiated by the investor.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: AMCs are required to implement systems to monitor investment thresholds daily and prevent breaches due to investor redemptions.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not explicitly stated in this circular, but non-compliance would likely result in regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_title: Handling Active Breach of Minimum Investment Threshold
key_clauses.clause_content: In case of any active breach of the Minimum Investment Threshold by an investor, including through transactions on stock exchanges or off-market transfers, all units of such investor held across investment strategies of the concerned SIF shall be frozen for debit, and a notice of 30 calendar days shall be given to such investor to rebalance the investments in order to comply with the Minimum Investment Threshold.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: AMCs must freeze units and notify investors who breach the minimum investment threshold, giving them an opportunity to rectify the breach.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not explicitly stated in this circular, but failure to freeze units and provide notice would likely result in regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: In case investor rebalances his/her investments in SIF within the notice period of 30 calendar days, the units of SIF of such investor shall be unfreezed, and no further action shall be taken with regard to compliance with Minimum Investment Threshold.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: If the investor rectifies the breach within 30 days, the units are unfrozen, and no further action is required.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not applicable if the investor complies.

key_clauses.clause_title: Automatic Redemption for Failure to Rebalance
key_clauses.clause_content: In case the investor fails to rebalance the investments within the aforesaid 30 calendar day period, the frozen units shall be automatically redeemed by the AMC, at the applicable Net Asset Value of the next immediate business day after the 30th calendar day of the notice period.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: AMCs are required to automatically redeem units if the investor fails to rebalance within the 30-day notice period.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Failure to automatically redeem units would likely result in regulatory action by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: For the purpose of SIF, the ‘Active Breach’ shall mean fall in the aggregate value of an investor’s total investment across all investment strategies of SIF, below the Minimum Investment Threshold of INR 10 lakh, on account of any transactions (i.e. redemption, transfer, sale etc.) initiated by the investor.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Defines what constitutes an 'Active Breach' for the purpose of this circular, clarifying the scope of the monitoring and enforcement requirements.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Misinterpreting the definition of 'Active Breach' could lead to incorrect application of the rules and potential regulatory action.

key_clauses.clause_title: Implementation by AMCs, RTAs, and Depositories
key_clauses.clause_content: The AMCs, RTAs and Depositories shall take necessary steps and put in place necessary systems for the implementation of this circular.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Mandates AMCs, RTAs, and Depositories to establish systems and procedures to comply with the circular's requirements.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Failure to implement necessary systems could result in regulatory action by SEBI.

documents.summary: This SEBI circular provides clarifications on regulatory provisions for Research Analysts (RAs) through Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) following the SEBI (Research Analysts) (Third Amendment) Regulations, 2024. key_clauses.clause_title: NISM Certification for Persons Associated with Research Services
key_clauses.clause_content: Persons associated with research services shall obtain the relevant certification from NISM as specified by SEBI within one year from the date of this circular or within the timeline as may be specified by SEBI.

key_clauses.clause_content: Consent by signature on the terms and conditions including most important terms and conditions (MITC) shall not be mandatory for the clients who are institutional investors or qualified institutional buyers. However, RAs/research entities are required to disclose the terms and conditions of research services including MITC to these clients.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Eases compliance for RAs by removing the mandatory consent requirement for institutional investors/QIBs, while still requiring disclosure of terms and conditions.

key_clauses.clause_content: Independent research analysts, part-time research analysts, individuals employed as research analyst or their associates shall not deal or trade any securities that the research analyst recommends or follows within 30 days before and 5 days after the publication of a research report on the subject company.

key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified, but non-compliance can lead to penalties and suspension or cancellation of registration.

documents.summary: This circular pertains to Industry Standards on minimum information to be provided to the Audit Committee and Shareholders for approval of Related Party Transactions (RPTs). It modifies Section III-B of the Master Circular to incorporate revised Industry Standards formulated by the Industry Standards Forum (ISF) and mandates listed entities to follow these standards from September 01, 2025. The circular also supersedes previous circulars on the same subject and directs industry associations and stock exchanges to publish the RPT Industry Standards and FAQs on their websites.

key_clauses.clause_title: Modification of Master Circular regarding information to Audit Committee for RPT approval
key_clauses.clause_content: Paragraph 4 under Part A of Section III-B of the Master Circular shall stand substituted by the following paragraph: “The listed entity shall provide the audit committee with the information as specified in the Industry Standards on “Minimum information to be provided to the Audit Committee and Shareholders for approval of Related Party Transactions”, while placing any proposal for review and approval of an RPT.”
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Listed entities must now adhere to the Industry Standards when providing information to the audit committee for RPT approval.

key_clauses.clause_title: Modification of Master Circular regarding information to Shareholders for RPT approval
key_clauses.clause_content: Paragraph 6 under Part B of Section III-B shall stand substituted by the following paragraph: “The notice being sent to the shareholders seeking approval for any RPT shall, in addition to the requirements under the Companies Act, 2013, include the information as part of the explanatory statement as specified in the Industry Standards on “Minimum information to be provided to the Audit Committee and Shareholders for approval of Related Party Transactions.”
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Listed entities must include information as specified in the Industry Standards in the explanatory statement sent to shareholders for RPT approval, in addition to the requirements under the Companies Act, 2013.

key_clauses.clause_content: The listed entities, from the effective date of this Circular, shall follow the aforesaid RPT Industry Standards to ensure compliance with Part A and Part B of Section III-B of the Master Circular read with Regulation 23(2), (3) and (4) of LODR Regulations.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Listed entities are mandated to comply with the RPT Industry Standards to ensure compliance with the Master Circular and LODR Regulations.

documents.summary: This circular revises the frequency of Product Advisory Committee (PAC) meetings as mandated in the 'Master Circular for Commodity Derivatives Segment'. Specifically, it modifies the meeting frequency requirement for agricultural commodities, reducing it to at least once a year, while maintaining the requirement of at least twice a year for other commodities or more frequently as needed.

However, in the case of agricultural commodities, the PAC shall meet at least once a year.

documents.summary: This SEBI circular introduces a structured Unified Payment Interface (UPI) address mechanism for SEBI-registered investor-facing intermediaries to collect funds from investors, aiming to enhance accessibility and safety in the securities market. It mandates intermediaries to obtain and make available a standardized, validated UPI ID to investors, while the use of this mechanism by investors remains optional. The circular outlines the structure of the dedicated UPI address, allocation framework, transaction limits, verification mechanism, responsibilities of various entities, and activity-wise timelines for implementation.

key_clauses.clause_title: Mandatory Adoption of Structured UPI Address by Intermediaries
key_clauses.clause_content: It is mandatory for intermediaries to obtain and make available the structured UPI address to their investors, although the use of this mechanism by investors remains optional. Intermediaries are advised and encouraged to actively promote and facilitate the adoption of this mechanism among their investors.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Intermediaries must invest in obtaining and implementing the new UPI system, and educate investors about its use. Failure to do so will result in non-compliance.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but presumed to be standard SEBI penalties for non-compliance.

key_clauses.clause_content: The UPI address consists of a Username (alphanumeric ID generated for the user followed by an abbreviation representing their intermediary segment) and a handle (@valid combined with the name of the self-certified syndicate banks).
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Intermediaries must adhere to the specified format when generating their UPI IDs. This ensures uniformity and ease of identification for investors.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but presumed to be standard SEBI penalties for non-compliance.

key_clauses.clause_content: UPI IDs with the handle @valid shall be exclusively designated for payment collection by intermediaries registered with SEBI under merchant category code 6211. The usage of these UPI handles for any activity other than the intended payment collection shall not be permitted.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Intermediaries are restricted to using the @valid UPI handles solely for payment collection purposes. Misuse of these handles will be considered a violation.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but presumed to be standard SEBI penalties for non-compliance.

key_clauses.clause_content: The upper limit of up to ₹5 lakhs per day for capital market transactions (done through UPI) shall be available, subject to periodic review and further evaluation as necessary.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This limits the amount that can be transacted via UPI in the capital markets, potentially affecting high-value transactions.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but presumed to be standard SEBI penalties for non-compliance.

key_clauses.clause_title: Verification of UPI IDs and Bank Account Details
key_clauses.clause_content: SEBI is developing a functionality named “SEBI Check” to allow investors to verify the authenticity of UPI IDs and confirm the bank details of an intermediary.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: This enhances investor protection by providing a tool to verify the legitimacy of intermediaries before making payments.
key_clauses.effective_date: Not specified, dependent on SEBI Check functionality launch.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not applicable as this is a SEBI initiative.

key_clauses.clause_content: Intermediaries must update their mobile number and email address in the SI Portal, obtain new UPI IDs from banks, discontinue the use of old handles (except for ongoing Mutual Funds SIPs), create investor awareness about new payment handles and “SEBI Check” functionality, and create awareness and educational content for investors by placing relevant FAQs on their websites.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Intermediaries have several responsibilities to ensure a smooth transition to the new UPI system and to educate investors about its use.
key_clauses.effective_date: Various dates as per the activity-wise timelines in Section 7.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Not specified in this circular, but presumed to be standard SEBI penalties for non-compliance.

key_clauses.clause_content: Self-Certified Syndicate Banks must obtain API access, issue UPI IDs only after verification using the utility, and do proper due diligence while issuing the UPI IDs.

documents.summary: This circular provides a framework for the issuance of Environment, Social, and Governance (ESG) debt securities, excluding green debt securities, such as social bonds, sustainability bonds, and sustainability-linked bonds. It outlines the definitions, disclosure requirements, responsibilities of issuers, and measures to mitigate the risk of purpose-washing, aiming to facilitate the raising of funds through these instruments while ensuring transparency and investor protection.

key_clauses.clause_content: Regulation 2(1)(oa) of the SEBI (Issue and Listing of Non-Convertible Securities) Regulations 2021 defines ESG debt securities as green debt securities, social bonds, sustainability bonds, sustainability-linked bonds, or any other type of bonds issued in accordance with international frameworks adapted to suit Indian requirements as specified by the Board.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Clarifies the scope of ESG debt securities under SEBI regulations, providing a basis for regulatory oversight and compliance.

key_clauses.clause_content: Regulation 12A of the SEBI NCS Regulations states that an issuer desirous of issuing and listing ESG Debt Securities shall comply with such conditions as may be specified by the Board.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Establishes the requirement for issuers to adhere to SEBI-specified conditions for issuing and listing ESG debt securities.

key_clauses.clause_content: This circular applies to ESG debt securities labelled as ‘social bonds’, ‘sustainability bonds’ and ‘sustainability-linked bonds’ which are listed or proposed to be listed on a recognized stock exchange.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Defines the scope of the circular's application to specific types of ESG debt securities.

key_clauses.clause_content: Debt securities shall be labelled as ‘social bonds’ or ‘sustainability bonds’ or ‘sustainability-linked bonds’ only if the funds raised are proposed to be utilised for financing or refinancing projects and/or assets aligned with recognized standards such as ICMA Principles/Guidelines, Climate Bonds Standard, ASEAN Standards, European Union Standards, or any framework specified by a financial sector regulator in India.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Sets conditions for labeling debt securities as social, sustainability, or sustainability-linked bonds, ensuring alignment with recognized standards.

key_clauses.clause_content: “Social Bonds” means a debt security issued for raising funds, subject to the conditions as may be specified by the Board from time to time, to be utilised for social project(s) that directly aim to address or mitigate a specific social issue and/or seek to achieve positive social outcomes especially but not exclusively for a target population, falling under specified categories.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Defines Social Bonds and specifies the categories of social projects eligible for funding through these bonds.

key_clauses.clause_content: ‘Sustainability bonds’ means a debt security issued for raising funds, subject to the conditions as may be specified by the Board from time to time, to be utilised for finance or re-finance of a combination of eligible green project(s) and social project(s) as specified under the definition of green bonds and social bonds respectively.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Defines Sustainability Bonds as those funding a combination of green and social projects.

key_clauses.clause_content: ‘Sustainability-linked bonds’ means a debt security which has its financial and/or structural characteristics linked to predefined sustainability objectives of the Issuer, subject to the condition that such objectives are measured through predefined Sustainability Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and assessed against predefined Sustainability Performance Targets (SPTs).
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Defines Sustainability-linked Bonds as those with financial characteristics tied to the issuer's sustainability objectives, measured by KPIs and SPTs.

key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers of social bonds must make initial disclosures in the offer document (as specified in Part I of Annexure-A) and provide continuous disclosures in their annual report and financial results (as specified in Part II of Annexure-A). They must also appoint an independent third-party reviewer/certifier (as specified in Part III of Annexure-A).
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Mandates specific disclosures and third-party review for social bonds to ensure transparency and accountability.

key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers of sustainability bonds must comply with the provisions specified for green debt security as specified in chapter IX of the NCS Master Circular and for social bonds as specified in Annexure-A of this circular.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Specifies that sustainability bonds must adhere to the disclosure requirements for both green debt securities and social bonds.

key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers of sustainability-linked bonds must make initial disclosures in the offer document (as specified in Part I of Annexure B) and provide continuous disclosures in their annual report and financial results (as specified in Part II of Annexure B). They must also appoint an independent third-party reviewer/certifier (as specified in Part III of Annexure B).
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Mandates specific disclosures and third-party review for sustainability-linked bonds to ensure transparency and accountability.

key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers of social bonds/sustainability bonds must maintain a decision-making process to determine the continuing eligibility of projects and ensure that funds are used only for the stated purpose.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Places responsibility on issuers to ensure the ongoing eligibility of projects and proper use of funds.

key_clauses.clause_content: Issuers must continuously monitor the social/sustainable impact of operations, avoid using funds for ineligible purposes, disclose instances of non-compliance, avoid misleading labels, quantify negative externalities, and avoid false claims of third-party certification. In case of non-compliance, early redemption of debt securities may be required by majority of debenture holders.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Imposes measures to prevent 'purpose-washing' and ensure the integrity of social and sustainability bonds.
key_clauses.penalty_consequences: Early redemption of debt securities may be required by majority of debenture holders.

key_clauses.clause_title: Post Listing Obligations for SME Exchange
key_clauses.clause_content: An Issuer who is eligible to list specified securities on SME exchange and intends to issue ESG debt securities shall have to comply with the post listing obligations as specified under ‘Continuous disclosure requirements’ specified in Annexure-A and Annexure-B, and paragraph 2 of Chapter IX (green Debt Securities) of SEBI NCS Master Circular bi-annually.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Specifies the post listing obligations for SME exchanges.

key_clauses.clause_content: The issuer shall appoint an independent third party reviewer/ certifier, to ascertain that the ESG labelled debt securities are in alignment with any of the recognized standards mentioned at paragraph V.3 and/ or paragraph V.4 above (including review/certification of the processes including project evaluation and selection criteria, project categories eligible for financing by social bonds, etc), in compliance with specified conditions.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Mandates the appointment of an independent third party reviewer/certifier to ensure compliance with recognized standards.

actionable_items.action_title: Comply with Disclosure Requirements for Social Bonds
actionable_items.action_description: Issuers intending to issue social bonds must make the initial disclosures specified in Part I of Annexure-A in the offer document and provide continuous disclosures as specified in Part II of Annexure-A in their annual report and financial results.

documents.summary: This circular addresses the issue of accumulation of unsold client securities in brokers' demat accounts after invocation of margin pledged securities and operational difficulties faced by brokers when clients sell pledged securities. It introduces a combined automated process for invocation and sale of pledged securities, including a 'Pledge release for early pay in' functionality and blocking of invoked securities for early pay-in in the client's demat account.

key_clauses.clause_title: Pledge Release for Early Pay-in Functionality
key_clauses.clause_content: Depositories shall provide a functionality of single instruction in the form of ‘Pledge release for early pay in’ to TM/CM wherein pledge will be released and early pay in block will be set up immediately in client demat account subject to pay in validation i.e. only to the extent of delivery obligation of that client as provided by CCs to depositories without the need for physical instruction or electronic instruction or DDPI/POA, in cases where client sells the securities which are pledged in favor of TM/CM as Margin pledged securities (including pledged funded stock) / CUSPA pledge.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Facilitates easier and faster processing of securities sold by clients that are under margin pledge, reducing operational burden on brokers and improving efficiency.

key_clauses.clause_title: Invocation and Blocking of Margin Pledged Securities for Early Pay-in
key_clauses.clause_content: In case of invocation of margin pledged securities (including pledged funded stock) of client by Trading member (TM), the invoked securities, other than mutual fund units that are not traded on the exchanges, shall be blocked for early pay-in in the client’s demat account with a trail being maintained in TM/CM’s ‘Client Securities Margin Pledge Account’ / ‘Client Securities under Margin Funding Account’. The pay in block in client’s demat account shall be subject to pay in validation i.e. only to the extent of delivery obligation of that client as provided by CCs to depositories.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Ensures that invoked securities are readily available for pay-in, preventing delays and potential defaults. It also maintains a clear audit trail of the invocation process.

key_clauses.clause_title: Invocation and Redemption of Mutual Fund Units
key_clauses.clause_content: In case of invocation of Mutual fund (MF) units that are not traded on the exchange, depositories shall provide a functionality of single instruction in the form of ‘invocation cum redemption’ wherein invoked MF units will come to the TM/CM’s ‘Client Securities Margin Pledge Account’, and go for auto redemption from the said account.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Streamlines the process for redeeming invoked mutual fund units, ensuring timely realization of funds for the broker.

key_clauses.clause_title: Handling of Invoked Securities when Client Account is Frozen
key_clauses.clause_content: In scenarios, where client’s trading account is frozen or client trading codes are marked as ‘Not permitted to trade’ or equivalent at the stock exchanges subsequent to creation of pledge, the invoked securities will come to demat account of TM/CM and the same shall be sold by TM/CM under the proprietary code. In order to prevent the accumulation of client securities in the demat account of TM/CM, it must be ensured by TM/CM that pay-in of securities is done on the same day of invocation.
key_clauses.regulatory_impact: Provides a mechanism for brokers to handle invoked securities when a client's account is frozen, preventing accumulation of securities and ensuring timely pay-in.

actionable_items.action_description: Depositories must implement the 'Pledge release for early pay in' functionality, allowing brokers to release pledges and set up early pay-in blocks in client demat accounts with a single instruction, subject to pay-in validation.

actionable_items.compliance_requirements: Functionality must ensure that the pledge is released and an early pay-in block is set up immediately in the client's demat account, limited to the client's delivery obligation as provided by Clearing Corporations.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Not Specified

actionable_items.implementation_timeline: On or before July 01, 2025, depositories must specify detailed operating guidelines. The functionality must be live by September 05, 2025.
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: The pay-in block must be subject to pay-in validation, limited to the client's delivery obligation as provided by Clearing Corporations.
actionable_items.documentation_needed: Not Specified

actionable_items.action_description: Depositories must provide a functionality of single instruction in the form of ‘invocation cum redemption’ wherein invoked MF units will come to the TM/CM’s ‘Client Securities Margin Pledge Account’, and go for auto redemption from the said account.
actionable_items.implementation_timeline: On or before July 01, 2025, depositories must specify detailed operating guidelines. The functionality must be live by September 05, 2025.

actionable_items.action_description: Trading Members (TM) and Clearing Members (CM) must ensure that when a client's trading account is frozen or marked as 'Not permitted to trade' after the creation of a pledge, the invoked securities are sold under the TM/CM's proprietary code, and pay-in of securities is done on the same day of invocation.
actionable_items.compliance_requirements: TM/CMs must sell the invoked securities under their proprietary code and ensure pay-in is completed on the same day of invocation to prevent accumulation of client securities.

actionable_items.monitoring_mechanism: Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations will likely monitor compliance through regular audits and reporting.
